citeinfo.origin: Grand Canyon Monitoring and Research Center
citeinfo.title: centerline_route_tenth_mile

descript.abstract: This coverage contains the centerline of the Colorado River from Glen Canyon Dam to the headwaters of Lake Mead. The centerline was digitized using orthophotography and an 8,000 CFS shoreline for guidance. Every effort was made to follow the main flow of the river while keeping the line somewhat equidistant from both shorelines. The Centerline coverage has been created to more accurately map locations along the Colorado River downstream of the Glen Canyon Dam. River mileage and river kilometers were developed from measurements along this line.
descript.purpose: This data set was developed to provide a digital river measurement system to be used by scientists performing research along the Colorado River.

cntorgp.cntorg: Grand Canyon Monitoring and Research Center

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.1.0.722

dataqual.complete: This dataset has undergone a review process to improve placement accuracy in regard to both the river's center and the most appropriate course of flow at 8,000 cfs. Hardcopy review mapbooks were sent to contributing scientists, GCMRC staff, and boatmen for review. Changes were incorporated where appropriate. River Mileage systems and river guide systems where derived from this line and reviewed using the same procedure.

cntorgp.cntorg: Grand Canyon Monitoring and Research Center, GIS Department

procstep.procdesc: The Centerline was initially created using the CENTERLINE option of the Add Arc command in ArcEdit 8.1 (ESRI). Two main datasets were used as reference for the on-screen digitizing process, March 2000 CIR orthophotos and LIDAR derived vectors. The LIDAR vectors include a shoreline coverage and an island coverage, both were used to determine the best location of the river's center. Both reference datasets were collected at 8,000 cfs steady flow discharge from Glen Canyon Dam. Diversions from the river's true center were made to account for obvious obstacles in the river such as boulders, rapids, sandbars, etc. and an attempt was made to follow the main river current in most areas.

Color infrared (CIR) aerial photography was collected in stereo with 60 percent forward overlap during low water level (8000 CFS) and scanned at a resolution of 14 microns (approximately 0.92 feet per pixel). Imagery was orthorectified using LIDAR data collected in March 2000. Airborne GPS data were used to control the aerial photography. Scanner: Intergraph PhotoScan TD Photo Digitizing System. Scanner Geometric Calibration: Standard Deviation (sigma) = 1.6710356970 Root Mean Square X = 1.9970393211 Root Mean Square Y = 0.9624905604 Scanner setting: Transmissivity: 0.0151 0.6610 Film Density: 1.8210 0.1778 Gamma: 1.75 Quality Control Procedures: Film was kept in airtight containers prior to scanning. Both the base and emulsion sides of the film were cleaned using a tacky roller system prior to scanning. Color adjustment was achieved by visually matching the tone, contrast, and brightness to the original film. Each scanned image was checked computationally for missing data. Quality Control Procedures for orthophoto production: After individual orthophotos were mosaiced into a regional database, the resulting orthophoto composite was visually inspected for tone balance and image distortion. In areas of image distortion, more suitable orthophoto imagery was inserted, when possible. Digitized shoreline and breakline vectors were superimposed on the orthphoto mosaic and visually inspected for accuracy and consistency

cntperp.cntorg: Grand Canyon Monitoring and Research Center

horizpa.horizpar: Digitized on-screen at approx. 1:5000 scale over March 2000 Orthophotos. Orthophoto base info: The horizontal RMS for the airborne GPS for this area of the project is: X - RMS = .707 meters Y - RMS = .291 meters The X-Y vector is .764 meters. Some Airborne GPS photo-center x and y residuals are as high as 1.8 meters.

vertacc.vertaccr: Orthophoto base info:The vertical RMS for the airborne GPS for this area of the project is: Z - RMS = 1.093 meters. Some Airborne GPS photo-center z residuals are as high as 2.646 meters

attracc.attraccr: The route and river mileages were checked against existing river guides for accuracy and completeness through formal review process.
